list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

sense.s: The twenty-eighth letter of the alphabet: called yaMCN. It is one of the letters termed soft, or weak, and is a letter of prolongation and of augmentation. As a numeral it signifies Ten.
I for yA frequently occurs in the phrase yarasuwla QllRehi, and in yaOayRuhaA.
I inserted to give fulness of sound to kesreh, see art. A.
Used lilUinokaAri, see Alf AlAstnkAr in art. A.

I with sheddeh followed by p converts a part. n. into a quasi-inf. n., as AlmaDoruwbiyRapu, “ the being beaten. ” So, by the relative I, yaMCu Alnisobapi, substs. and even particles are converted into abstract nouns of quality, as AisomiyRapN and kayofiyRapN.

yaA is the most common of vocative particles, used in calling to him who is near; [like O!]; and to him who is distant; [like Ho there! Holloa!]; and to him who is between near and distant; [like ho! what ho!]; (Ibn-el-Kátib, in the Káfiyeh, cited in TA, art. OayaA.) Pronounced with imáleh, see art. UimRaA.
yaAla for yaA Mla, see l.
yaAyaA and yaAyaho, see art. OayaA.
R. Q. 1. yaOoyaOahu, inf. n. yaOoyaOahN and yaOoyaMCN, [respecting the form of which latter see ZaOoZaOa,] He made a show of kindness, benignity, or favour to him. (K.)
UinRamaA huwa yaOoyaMCN [It is only making a show of kindness, &c.: or, perhaps, He is only one who makes a show of kindness, &c.,]. (L.)
yaOoyaOa biAlqawomi He called the people: (K: so too in the L, and this is the correct meaning: TA:) or he said to the people yaORayaORa, in order that they should assemble, or collect together. (K)
yaOoyaOa biAlUibili He called to the camels by the cry OaIo, (whence the verb is formed by transposition, TA,) to quiet them. (K.)
yaOoyaMCN The cry, or crying, of the bird called yuWoyuW. (K.)
[See also the verb.]
See art. OayaA.

yuWoyuWN A certain bird (S, K) of prey, (S,) resembling the [kind of hawk called] baAXaq: (S, K:) it is of the birds called Suquwr, [pl. of SaqorN,] as are also the baAziI and the XaAhiyn and the zurRaq and the baAXaq: (AHát in TA, in art. bXq:) accord. to Dmr, it is a small bird, short-tailed, the temperament of which is, in comparison with that of the bAXq, cold and moist; for it is more patient, or enduring, and heavier in motion: the people of Egypt and Syria, he adds, call it jalamN, on account of the lightness and swiftness of its wings: (TA:) pl. yaOLYiIu, and, in a verse, yaOLYiIo. (S.)
Also, accord. to AA, The head, or uppermost part, of a vessel in which kuHol (collyrium) is kept: mentioned before as called buWobuWN, which is perhaps a mistake for yWyW. (TA.)

1. yaYisa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) mina AlXRaIoCi, (S, A *, Msb,) aor. yayoYasu and yayoYisu, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter of which is extr., (Sb, S, M, K,) like yaHosibu, aor. of Hasiba, and yanoEimu, aor. of naEima, (As, S, TA,) and is of the dial. of the higher classes of Mudar, as are also the similar instances, but the former is of the dial. of the lower classes of the Mudar; (AZ, S, Msb, TA;) or, as Sb says, accord. to his companions, the verb was originally of two forms, yaYisa, aor. yayoYasu, and yaOasa, aor. yayoYisu, and a compound [which is yaYisa having yayoYisu for its aor.] was then formed from the two; but as to wamiqa, aor. yamiqu, and wafiqa, aor. yafiqu, and warima. aor. yarimu, and waliIa, aor. yaliI, and waviqa, aor. yaviqu, and wariva, aor. yarivu, in each of these only one form is allowable, with the kesr; (S, TA;) and some change the second I of the aor. of yaYisa into A, and say yaAyasu and yaMCasu; (Mbr, S, TA;) and I'Ab reads, in the Kur. xii. 87, yiyYasu, after the manner of the dial. of those who pronounce the first letter of the aor. with kesr excepting such as is with I [for its first letter], (K, TA,) which dial, is that of Temeem and Keys and Hudheyl and Asad; (Ks, Lh, TA;) the case of I being made an exception by them because kesr with that letter is difficult of pronunciation; (Sb, TA;) but some of the Benoo-Kelb pronounce I also with kesr, which is extr.; (Fr, Lb, TA:) and this is done in the instances of yiyYasu and yiyjalu because one I is here strengthened by another; (K, TA;) [I find also, in a copy of the M, yaYiysu, as an extr. form of the aor. of this verb, on the authority of Sb; but it is doubtless a mistranscription for yiyYasu; and there is another evident mistranscription in a quotation from Sb immediately following in that copy, relating to aors. of the form of yiyYasu, which has been rendered correctly above, in the present work, from the TA;] inf. n. yaOosN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and yaOasN, (TA,) or yaMsN, (as in a copy of the M,) and yaMsapN; (Ibn-'Abbád, M, K, TA [but in a MS. copy of the K I find it written yaOasapN; and in the CK, yaOosap;]) and UiyaAsN is also used as an inf. n. of this verb, though properly an inf. n. of 4; (Msb;) He despaired of the thing; syn. of the inf. n. qunuwT, (S, A, K,) contr. of rajaMCN: (M, A, K:) or he cut off hope of the thing: (A, K: *) or his hope of the thing became cut off: (Mgh:) and UisotayoYasa↓ signifies the same, (S, A, K,) in like manner followed by mano; (S;) and so does UitRaOasa↓, (S, K,) [originally UiytaOasa,] of the measure UifotaEala, but with incorporation [of the I into the t]. (S.) It is allowable to transpose the letters of yaYisa, so as to say Oayisa; but not those of the inf. n. (Msb.) There is not a word in the Arabic language commencing with I followed by C except yaYisa [and its derivatives] (IKtt) [and yaOayaOa and its derivatives, and words commencing with an augmentative I followed by a radical
yaAu^a
]. The expression laA yaOosa mino TuwlK. occurring in a description of Mohammad, means that his stature was such as would not make [one] to despair of his height; for he was nearer to tallness than he was to shortness: (K, * TA:) yOs is here an indeterminate noun governed in
the accus. case by the negative lA: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the words are, laA yaAYisa mino TuwlK, [in the CK, erroneously, lA yAyasu,] meaning, that his height was not despaired of; i. e., he who vied with him in tallness would not despair of him on account of his excessive height: (K, TA:) so that yaAYis is here in the sense of mayoWuws, like maMCN daAfiqN in the sense of madofuwqN. (TA.)
[Hence,] yaYisato AlmaroOahu The woman was, or became, barren. (Msb.)

yaYisa, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. yayoYasu and yayoYisu, (M,) also signifies (tropical:) He knew; syn. Ealima; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) in the dial. of En-Nakha'; (S, Msb;) or, accord. to El-Kelbee, (M,) or Ibn-El-Kelbee, (TA,) in the dial. of Wahbeel, a tribe of En-Nakha'; or, accord. to El-Kásim Ibn-Maan, of the dial. of Hawázin. (M, TA.) So in the Kur. [xiii. 30] Oafalamo yayoYasi QlRaciyna MmanuwA [Do not then those who have believed know?]: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, do not then those who have believed know with a knowledge wherewith they despair of its being otherwise than what they know? or the meaning is, do not then those who have believed despair of the belief of those whom God has described as those who will not believe? (M, TA;) but I' Ab (M, TA) and 'Alee and others (TA) used to read Oafalamo yatabayRani QlRaciyna MmanuwA; and I'Ab said that he thought that the writer had written yayoYas in a state of drowsiness. (M *, TA.) Soheym Ibn-Wetheel El-Yarboo'ee also uses the verb in this sense, in a verse cited in art. ysr, voce yasara, q. v. (S, M *). [Z-says,] You say, qado yaYisotu OanRaka rajulu SidoqK, meaning, (tropical:) I have known [that thou art a good man], because with eager desire is restlessness, and with the cessation thereof is quiet and tranquility; wherefore it is said, AlyaOosu OaHadu AlrRaAHatayoni [Despair is one of the two states of rest.] (A, TA.)

4. OayoOasahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) inf. n. UiyaAsN, (L, Mgh, Msb,) of the same measure as kitaAbN, (Msb,) originally UiyoMsN, (L, Msb,) like UiyoEaAsN, (L,) and UiyomaAnN, (Msb,) He made him to despair: (S, M, A, K:) or to cut off hope: (A:) or to cease to have hope: (Mgh:) mano kacaA of such a thing: (S:) as also Myasahu↓ [from Oayisa]. (Mgh, K.)
[Hence,] OayoOusahaA QllRehu God made her to be, or become, barren. (Msb.)
8: see 1.

yaOasN Phthisis, or consumption; syn. silRN; (M, K;) because he who is affected by it is despaired of; (M;) or [because] the first who was affected by it was AlyaOasu, (K, TA,) or UiloyaAs, (TA,) the son of Mudar the son of Nizár: (K, TA:) or, as Suh says, in the R, this disease was called daMCu yaAs, or daMCu UiloyaAsa, because AlyAs the son of Mudar died of it. (TA.)
yaWusN: see yaAYisN.
yaWuwsN: see yaAYisN.
yaYiysN: see yaAYisN.
yaAYisN (M, Mgh, Msb) and yaYiys↓ (M) and yaWuwsN↓ (S, M, A, K) and yaWusN↓ (M, K) Despairing: (S, M, A, Mgh, K:) but the third has an intensive signification, (Bd, xli. 49,) [and so the last.]
yaAYisapN, A barren woman. (Msb.)
mayoWuwsN minohu Despaired of. (M, Mgh, Msb. *)
2. xarRabuwhu wyabRabuwhu [They rendered it waste, and made it desolate: see yabaAbN]. (A.)

yabaAbN Vacant; in which there is nothing; (Sh;) in which there is no one. (T.) OaroDN ybAbN A land that is in a state of rain, or waste, uninhabited, depopulated, deserted, desolate, in a state the contrary of flourishing: (S, K:) an uninhabited land, accord. to some. (Msb.) xaraAbN ybAbN: in this case, the latter word is merely an imitative sequent to the former: (Sh, Msb:) or it is not so; (S;) [and therefore the meaning is A very desolate waste, or the like; ybAb being added to strengthen the signification of xrAb: or merely a waste, or the like; ybAb being an explicative adjunct]. daAruhumo xaraAbo yabaAbo laA HaArisa walaA baAbo [Their dwelling is desolate, vacant; there is (to it) neither guard nor door]. (A.) HawoDN ybAbN A tank, or cistern, that is empty; containing no water. (A.) OamosaI mina AlOaniysi ybAbFA It became devoid of inhabitants: occurring in a verse of Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah. (TA.)

1. yabisa, aor. yayobasu (S, M, A, Msb, K) and yaAbasu (K) and yayobisu, (S, M, Msb, K,) which latter is extr., (S, M, K,) so that it is like yaYisa, (TA,) inf. n. yubosN (S, M, Msb *) and yabasN (M, Msb, * TA) and yabosN (M) and yubuwsapN, (K [but not there said to be an inf. n., being only mentioned there in an explanation of the word yabasN, and accord. to general rule it would be an inf. n. of yabusa, which is probably an obsolete form,]) It was, or became, dry; or it dried, or dried up; after having been moist, humid, succulent, or the like: (A, Msb, K:) or, [rather,] it was, or became, dry; or it dried, or dried up: and also, [but perhaps tropically,] it was, or became, stiff, rigid, tough, firm, resisting pressure, or hard: [contr. of raTuba:] yubosN signifying the contr. of ruTuwbapN: (M:) yubuwsapN is a quality which necessarily implies difficulty of assuming form and of becoming separated and of becoming united: (KT:) and AitRabasa↓, (S, M, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S,) the I being changed into t, (M,) as well as [its original form] Aiytabasa, (TA [there written Atabasa because it has the conjunction wa prefixed to it]) aor. [of the former] yatRabisu and [of the latter] yaAtabisu, (M,) signifies the same as yabisa: (M, K:) or is quasipass. of yabRasahu↓ [and therefore signifies it became dried, or dried up; &c.]; (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, S;) [as also tybRs↓, occurring in the TA, art. Eks.] You say, yabisa AlnRabaAtu [The plant, or herbage, became dry; &c.] (S, K.) And yabisati AlOaroDu The land lost its water and moisture; its water and moisture went away. (M.)

[Hence, yabisato TabiyEatuhu (assumed tropical:) He became costive. And] yabisa maA bayonahumaA (tropical:) [That friendship which was between them two became withered; (see 2, and see also varFI;) i. e.,] they became disunited, each from the other; the bond of friendship that united them, each to the other, became severed; syn. taqaATaEaA. (A, TA.)

Hence also, (M,) Aiybaso↓, (so in a copy of the M [agreeably with an explanation of its part. n. yaAbisN, q. v., and in a copy of the A written Ayobaso,]) or Oayobiso, [from Oayobasa,] like Oakorimo, (K,) (tropical:) Be thou silent; or cease thou from speaking: (M, A, K:) said to a man. (M.)
2. ybRshu, (S, A, K;) inf. n. tayobiysN, (S,) He dried it; made it dry; [&c.; see 1;] (S, A, K;) as also Oayobasahu↓. (M, A, K.)

[Hence the saying,] OuEiycuka biQllRehi Oano tuyabRisa raHimFA maboluwlapF (tropical:) [I pray that thou mayest be preserved by God from thy withering a freshened tie of relationship]. (A, TA.) And laA tuwbisi AlvRaraI bayoniI wabayonaka (tropical:) [Wither not the fresh and vigorous friendship, between me and thee; i. e., sever not thou the firm bond of friendship that unites me and thee: see yabisa maA bayonahumaA; and see also varFI]. (A, TA.)
3. yAbshu (assumed tropical:) He treated him with dryness and hardness, or niggardliness; syn. qaAsaHahu; (L, K, art. qsH;) i. e. EAmlh bAlybs wAlXdRh. (TK, in that art.) [See yaAbisN.]
4. Aybst AlOaroDu The land had its plants or herbage, (A,) or its leguminous plants, (Yaakoob, S, K,) drying up, or dried up: (Yaakoob, S, A, K:) or became abundant in its dry plants or herbage. (M.)
Aybst AlnRaAqapu The she-camel became milkless. (TA, voce wajRabato.)
Aybs Alqawomu The people journeyed in the land: (K:) or in the dry land; (TA;) like as you say OajorazuwA from AlOaroDu Aljuruzu. (S, TA.)
Oayobiso: see 1, last signification.
Aybshu: see 2, in two places.
5: see 1.
8. AitRabasa Aiytabasa, aor. yatRabisu and yaAtabisu: see 1.
yabosN: see 1:
and see yaAbisN, throughout.
yubosN: see 1:
and see yaAbisN, in two places.
yabasN: see 1:
and see yaAbisN, throughout.
yabisN: see yaAbisN.
yabaAsN: see yaAbisN.

yabaAsi, like qiTaAmi, [as a proper name,] The pudendum; syn. AlsRawoCapu: or the anus; syn. Alfunoduwrapu; (K, TA [in one copy of the K, Alqunoduwrapu; and in the CK, AlqinodaCowapu;]) i. e., AlAisotu: on the authority of IAar. (TA.)
yabuwsN: see yaAbisN; for the latter, throughout.
yabiysN: see yaAbisN; for the latter, throughout.

yaAbisN Dry, or dried up, after having been moist, humid, succulent, or the like: (A, Msb, K:) or, [rather,] dry, or dried up, or exsiccated: and also, [but perhaps tropically,] stiff, rigid, tough, firm, resisting pressure, or hard: [see 1:] (M:) pl. yubRasN (M) and yabosN↓, which latter is like rakobN as pl. of rAkibN: (ISk, S, Msb:) and yubosN↓ is a dial. form. of yabosN: (A'Obeyd, S:) or yabosN is [rather] a quasi-pl. of yaAbisN, as is also yabasN↓: (M:) or this last is used by poetic license for yabosN: (TA:) also, (S, M,) yabosN↓ signifies the same as yaAbisN, (S, M, Msb, K,) as also yabasN↓, (M,) and yabisN↓, (M, K,) and yabiysN↓, (K,) and yabowsN↓, (M,) and yabaAsN↓, (TA,) and Oayobasu↓: (K:) or yabasN↓ signifies dry from its origin, not having been known moist: (K:) but yabosN↓ is applied to a thing dry after having been known to be moist: (TA:) and as to the path of Moses, [to which the former of the last two epithets is applied in the Kur. xx. 79,] it had never been known as a path either moist or dry, for God only showed it to them created such; but the epithet is also read with sukoon to the b, because, though it had not been a path, it was a place wherein had been water and which had dried up: (K, TA:) the latter reading is that of El-Hasan El-Basree: and El-Aamash read the word with kesr to the b: (TA:) Th [however] says, (S,) you say HaTabN yabosN↓, dry fire-wood, as though it were so naturally: (S, Msb:) [and J says,] yabasN↓ signifies a place dry after having been moist; and so in the instance in the Kur. mentioned above: (S:) [and Fei says,] it signifies a place that has had in it water which has gone away; or, as Az says, a path in which is no moisture: (Msb:) [and ISd says,] yabosN↓ and yabas↓ signify a place that is dry: and in like manner, applied to land (OaroD), of which the water and pasturage have dried up: and the latter, so applied, (assumed tropical:) hard; (M;) as also yaAbisN (tropical:) applied to a stone: (A:) yabysN↓ is [generally] applied to a plant, or herbage, as signifying dry, or dried up; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also [sometimes] yaAbisN; (M, K;) the former being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Msb:) or it is so applied to herbs, or leguminous plants, of the sort termed OaHoraAr [that are eaten without being cooked, or that are slender and succulent, &c.], (As, K,) and of the sort termed cukuwr [that are hard and thick, or thick and rough, &c.]; (As, TA;) and [so As, in the TA; and so in some copies of the K; but in the CK, or] those herbs and leguminous plants that become scattered when they dry up; (As, K;) as also yubosN↓ and yabosN↓; (TA;) but not to what is dry of the HaliIR and SilRiyaAn and Halamap. (As, TA.)

[Hence,] Almafoluwju AlyaAbisu AlXRiqRi (assumed tropical:) The palsied of whom the half is without sensation and without motion. (Mgh.) And rajulN yaAbisN mina AlsRukori (AHn) app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A man as though he were dead and dried up in consequence of much intoxication. (M.) [And yAabisu AlTRabiyEapi (assumed tropical:) Costive.] And sakoraAnu yaAbisN (assumed tropical:) Intoxicated so much as not to speak; as though the wine had dried him up by its heat. (M.) And OataAnN yabosapN↓ (IAar, M) and yabasapN↓ (Th, M) (assumed tropical:) A she-ass dry and lean. (M.) And XaApN yabosN↓ and yabasN↓ (AO, S, M, K) (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, without milk: (AO, S, M, K:) or whose milk has stopped, and her udder become dry. (M.) And UimoraOapN yabasapN↓ (assumed tropical:) A woman who has no milk: pl. yabasaAtN and OayobaAsN and [quasi-pl. n.] yaAbisN [like jaAmilN and baAqirN]. (TA, from the Moheet.) And EiroqN yabiysN↓ (assumed tropical:) [A dry duct], meaning, penis. (Lh, M.) And XaEarN yaAbisN (tropical:) Hair upon which no effect is produced by moistening with water nor with oil; (A, TA *;) which is the worst sort thereof. (TA.) And yabiysu AlmaMCi↓ (tropical:) Dry sweat: (M, A:) or [simply] sweat. (AA, S, K.) And rajulN yaAbisN and yabiysN↓ (tropical:) A man having little good: (A:) and AimoroOapN yaAbisapN and yabiysN↓ (A, TA) and yabasN↓ (S, K, TA) (tropical:) a woman having little good: (A:) or in whom is no good: (K, TA:) or who does not cause one to obtain any good. (S.) And bayonahumaA varFI Oayobasu↓ (tropical:) Between them two is disunion. (A, TA.)
Oayobasu [comp. and superl. of yaAbisN].
[Hence the saying,] Oayobasu mina AlSRaxori (tropical:) Harder than rock. (A.)
See also yaAbisN, near the beginning and at the end.

AlOayobasu, as a subst., not an epithet, (AHeyth,) The part of the shin-bone, in the middle of the shank, which, when pressed, pains one, (AHeyth, K,) and when it is broken, the leg is lost: (AHeyth:) or AlOayobasaAni signifies the parts of the two shanks upon which is no flesh: (S:) or the parts of the two shanks of a horse upon which the flesh is dry, or tough: (AO:) or the shank-bones (M, TA) of the fore leg and hind leg: (TA:) or what appears of these: (M, TA:) or the parts above the kaEobAani and zanodaAni [app. here meaning the two ankles and wrists]: (A:) pl. OayaAbisu: (S, K:) which is also applied to such parts as are like the hock, or hough, and the shank. (TA.)
Also, the pl., Hard things upon which swords are tried. (K.)
OaroDN muwbisapN [originally muyobisapN] Land of which the plants, or herbage, are drying up, or dried up. (A.)
riyjN miybaAsN [A very drying wind]. (TA, voce nakobaMCu.)

Q. 1. yaronaOa liHoyatahu (K, TA; in the CK, [erroneously,] taranRaOa;) He dyed his beard with yrnRO. (K.) A strange verb as to its form, (K,) which [except in its final vowel] is that of an aorist, though it is a preterite. (TA.) Mentioned in the L in art. rnO (q. v.), on the authority of IJ; and there also by ISd; and AHei and others assert the I to be augmentative. [If so, the verb is a quasi-quadriliteral-radical word.] F follows Sgh, in mentioning it here. (TA.)

yuranRaON (S, K) and yaranRaON and yuranRaMCN (K) and yuranRaA (without C) and (accord. to [the Bári', as mentioned in] the TA, art. rnO,) yaronaON and yuronaON and (accord. to MF, who omits the two forms here immediately preceding,) yaranRaACN and yaranRaA, without C, (TA,) i. q. HinRaACN (S, K) [The plant Lawsonia inermis]. See also art. rnO, where the word is written [erroneously in my opinion] yarunRaON. Accord. to IB (not IJ [as in the CK]), the may only be omitted when the word is pronounced with dammeh to the I. (TA.)

1. yasara, aor. yabosiru, [respecting the form of which see the same verb in a different sense below,] inf. n. yasorN and yasarN [and mayosuwrN (see yusorN below)], He was, or became, gentle, and tractable, submissive, manageable, or easy; (M, K;) said of a man, and of a horse: (M:) and yusira [app. signifies the same: and] is said of speech, and of a thing or an affair; signifying, [when relating to the former,] it was gentle, or [when relating to the latter,] easy; like suEida AlrRajulu [as
syn. with saEida], and nuHisa [as syn. with naHisa]. (Bd, xvii. 30.) See also tysRr.
yasarato, said of a woman: see Oayosarato

yasura, aor.
yasura
, It (a thing) was, or became, little in quantity: (A, Msb:) contemptible; paltry; of no weight or worth. (A.)
yasaraniI, aor. yayosiruniI, (AHn, M, K,) inf. n. yasorN, (AHn, M,) He (a man, AHn, M) came on, or from the direction of, my left hand. (AHn, M, K.) See also 3.

yasara, [aor. yayosiru, inf. n. yasorN,] He divided anything into parts, or portions. (TA.) You say, yasarotu AlnRaAqapa I divided the flesh of the she-camel into parts or portions. (TA.) And yasaruwA Aljazuwra They slaughtered the she-camel and divided its limbs, (S,) or portions, (TA,) among themselves; (S, TA;) as also, accord. to Aboo-'Omar ElJarmee, UitRasaruwhaA↓, aor. yatRasiruwnahaA, inf. n. UitRisaArN; and he adds that some people say, yaOotasiruwnahaA, inf. n. QnotisaArN, with hemz; and humo muWotasiruwna; like as they say in the case of UitRaEada. (S.) Soheym Ibn-Wetheel El-Yarboo'ee says,

L.foreign: Oalamo tayoYasuwA OanRiI Qbonu faArisi zahodami

sense.s: [I say to them, in the ravine, when they divide me among themselves, deciding what shares they shall severally have in me, Know ye not that I am the son of the rider of Zahdam, and that ye may obtain a great ransom for me?] for capture had befallen him, and they played with [gaming-] arrows for him. (S, TA. [but in the latter, instead of tayoYasuwA, we find taEolamuwA, which signifies the same.]) You say also, UitRasaruwA↓, aor. yatRasiruwna and yaOotasiruwna; (K;) and tayAasaruwA↓; (M, K;) They divided among themselves the slaughtered camel. (M, K.)

[Hence,] yasara, aor. yayosiru, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) in the [second] I is not suppressed as it is in yaEidu and its cöordinates [having w for the first radical], (S,) and yiysaru, like yiyjalu, in the dial. of the Benoo-Asad, (TA,) inf. n. yasorN, (M, TA,) or mayosirN, (A,) He played at the game called Almayosir; (M, Msb, K;) he played with gamingarrows. (S, A, Msb.)

2. ysRrhu, (inf. n. tayosiyrN, M, &c.) He (God, A, Msb) made it, or rendered it, easy; facilitated it. (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, yusRirato EalayohaA AlwilaAdapu The act of bringing forth was rendered easy to her. (A.)

He made his circumstances ample; he made his condition, or his way or course [likacaA to such a thing], easy, or smooth: (Sb, M:) he accommodated, adapted, or disposed, him, liloyusoraI [to easy things, or affairs, or circumstances; or to the easier, or easiest, way]: (S. A, [in the latter of which this is given as a proper, not tropical, signification:]) (tropical:) he prepared, or made ready, him or it, likacaA for such a thing. (A [in which this signification is said to be tropical.]) tayosiyrN relates to both good and evil: (M, K:) as in the following instances in the Kur; [xcii. 7, 10;] fasanuyasRiruhu liloyusoraI, and liloEusoraI, (M,) [We will facilitate, or smooth, his way, or] We will accommodate him, or adapt him, or dispose him, [to a state of ease, and to a state of difficulty, or (as explained in the TA, art. Esr,) to punishment, and a difficult case:] (S, A:) or We will prepare him for paradise, and for hell: (Jel:) or We will prepare him to return to good, or righteous, conduct, [and to persevere in evil, or unrighteous, conduct; the former leading to ease, and the latter to difficulty:] (Fr, TA:) or We will prepare him for that habit of conduct which leads to ease, such as the entering paradise, and for that which leads to difficulty, such as the entering hell: from ysRr Alfarasa, meaning, he prepared the horse for riding, by saddling and bridling. (Bd.) It is said in a trad. waqado yusRira lahu TahuwrN (assumed tropical:) And water for ablution had been prepared and put for him. (TA.)
yasRara AlrRajulu, (inf. n. tayosiyrN, K,) The man's camels, and his sheep or goats, brought forth with ease, (IAar, M, K), and none of them perished. (IAar, M.)

yasRarati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, abounded in milk, (S, M, A, K,) and in like manner, AlUibilu the camels, (M,) and [so in the S, M, A, but in the K or] in offspring: (S, M, A, K:) and they brought forth: and they were ready to bring forth: and they abounded. (TA.) A poet (namely Aboo-Useydeh Ed-Debeeree, TA) says,
(S, M) They two are our two chiefs, as they assert; but they are only our chiefs inasmuch as their sheep, or goats, abound in milk and in offspring. (TA.)
See also Oayosarato.

3. yAsrhu, [inf. n. muyaAsarapN] He was gentle towards him; acted gently towards him; treated him with gentleness; syn. laAyanahu: (M, A, K:) he was easy, or facile, with him; syn. saAhalahu. (S, K.) Ex., cited by Th, from a poem: Uino yaAsarotahumo yasaruwA If thou treat them with gentleness, they become gently. (M.) And yaAsara AlXRariyka He was easy, or facile, with the partner. (TA, from a trad.)

yAsr, (inf. n. muyaAsarapN, K,) He took the left-hand side or direction; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also tyAsr↓; (S, Msb, K;) which latter is the contr. of tyAmn: (K:) or tayaAsaruwA↓ they took the lefthand side or direction; contr. of tayaAmanuwA. (A.) You say, yaAsiro biOaSoHaAbika Take thou the left-hand side or direction with thy companions; (S, A;) as also tayaAsaro; but some disapprove of this latter. (S.) And yaAsara biAlqawomi He took the left-hand side or direction with the people; as also yasara bihimo↓ aor. yayosiru; accord. to Sb. (M, TA.)

4. Oayosarato She (a woman, M) brought forth with ease; she had an easy birth; (M, A, K;) as also ysRrt↓, (M, IKtt,) which is in like manner said of a she-camel; (M;) or, as in the copies of the K, yasarato, without teshdeed. (TA.) One says, in praying (M, A) for a pregnant woman, (A,) Oayosarato waOacokarato May she have an easy birth, (Lh, M, A,) and may she bring forth a male child. (Lh, M.) See the contr., OaEosarato.

Aysr, (S, M, &c.,) aor. yuwsiru, in which the [radical] I is changed into w because it is quiescent and preceded by damm, (S,) inf. n. UiysaArN (M, Mgh, K) and yusorN; (M, K;) accord. to Kr and Lh, but correctly the latter is a simple subst., (M,) He became possessed of competence, or sufficiency; or of richness, or wealth, or opulence; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and abundance. (Msb.)
Oayomanotu UibiliI waOayosarotuhaA I put my camels aside on the right hand and the left. (A.)

5. tysRr It (a thing, M, Msb) was, or became, facilitated, or easy; (M, A, Msb, K, TA;) contr. of difficult, hard, strait, or intricate; (TA;) as also Astysr↓. (M, A, Msb, K.) You say, OaxaconaA maA tayasRara, and maA Qsotayosara↓, We took what was easy [of obtainment, or of attainment]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the eleemosinary tax called wayajoEalu mEahaA XaAtayoni Uini, zakaAp lahu Oawo EiXariyna dirohamFA QsotayosarataA↓ And he shall put with it, or them, two sheep, or goats, if they be easy to him [to give], or twenty dirhems. (TA.) And in the Kur, [ii. 192,] mina AlhadoIi famaA Qsotayosara↓ What is easy [to give], of camels and kine and sheep or goats: or, as some say, either a camel or a cow or a sheep or goat. (M, TA.)

Also, tysRr lahu, (S, TA,) and lh Astysr↓, (S, K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, or an affair, K) was, or became, prepared, or made ready for him: (S, K, TA:) [and he prepared himself for it.] It is said in a trad., qado tayasRaraA liloqitaAli (assumed tropical:) They had both prepared themselves, or made themselves ready, for fight. (TA, from a trad.)
tayasRarati AlbilaAdu (tropical:) The countries became abundant in herbage, or in the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA, from a trad.)

6. tayaAsaruwA [They were gentle, or acted gently, one towards another; they treated one another with gentleness: (see 3, of which it is the quasipass.)] they were easy, or facile, one with another; syn. tsAhlwA; (K, * TA;) tayaAsurN is the contr. of taEaAsurN. (S, art. Esr.) It is said in a trad., tayaAsaruwA fiI AlSRadaAqi Be ye easy, or facile, not exorbitant, one with another, with respect to dowry. (TA.)
See also 3.
And see 1, latter part.
8: see 1, in two places.
10: see 5, in five places.

yasorN (TA) and yasarN↓, (M, A, K, TA,) [each an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet,] and yaAsirN, (K, TA,) Easy and gentle in tractableness, submissiveness, or manageableness; applied to a man and to a horse: (TA:) or [simply] easy; facile; (M, A, K;) as also yusorN↓ (TA) and yasiyrN, (Msb), this last being syn. with hayRinN, (S, K,) and signifying not difficult, gayoru EasiyrK, (A,) and mayosuwrN↓ [respecting which see also EusorN, pl. mayaAsiyru]. (A.) Hence, yasaraAtN↓, pl. of yasorapN and yasarapN, applied to the legs of a beast, signifies Easy: (M:) or light, or active, legs of a beast: (S, TA:) or light, or active, and obedient, legs of a beast of carriage: (A:) or the legs of a she-camel: and you say also, UinRa qawaAYima hecaA Alfarasi yasaraAtN xifaAfN, meaning, verily the legs of this horse are obedient and light or active. (TA.) [Hence also,] wilaAdapN yasorN [An easy birth, or bringing forth]. (A.) And waladato waladahaA yasorFA She brought forth her child easily: (M, K *:) said of a woman: (M:) or yasarFA↓. (CK.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa hecaA AldRiyna yusorN↓ Verily this religion is easy; liberal; one having little straitness. (TA.) You say also, xuco mayosuwrahu↓ wadaEo maEosuwrahu [Take thou what is easy thereof, and leave thou what is difficult]. (A.) And mayosuwrN↓ is applied to a saying, or speech: (A:) so in the Kur. xvii. 30; meaning, gentle; (Bd, Jel;) easy: (Jel:) or quwolN mayosuwrN↓ means prayer for mayosuwr, i. e., for yusor [q. v.]. (Bd.)

fatolN yasorN [The twisting a rope or cord towards the left, by rolling it against the body from right to left; or] the twisting downwards, by extending the right hand towards the body [and so rolling the rope or cord downwards against the body or thigh, which is the usual way of twisting]; (S, A *, K;) contr. of XazorN. (M, A, TA)
TaEonN yasorN The thrusting, or piercing, [straight forward; or] opposite the face: (S, M, K:) opposed to XazorN, which is from one's right and one's left. (TA.) See an ex. voce Xazarahu.

yusorN [Easiness; facility;] contr. of EusorN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also yusurN↓; (S, Msb, TA;) [and yusoraI↓; (see 3, where it is variously explained;)] and mayosuwrN↓ is the contr. of maEosuwrN, [and therefore signifies as above; or easy; facile;] (S;) or this last signifies, (accord. to the lexicologists, M,) what is made easy; or facilitated; or (accord. to Sb, M, [but see maEaquwlN,]) it is an inf. n. of the measure mafoEuwlN, (M, K,) [used in the sense of yusorN as explained above,] of the same kind as [its contr.] maEosuwrN; and Abu-l-Hasan says, that this is the truth; for it has no unaugmented verb, and inf. ns. of this measure are not of verbs which are in use, but only of imaginary unaugmented triliteral-radical verbs, as in the case of majoluwdN, which is [really] from tajalRada. (M.) For examples of yusorN, see EusorN.

Also, (accord. to the M; but in the K, or; and in both of these lexicons the signification here following is placed first;) and in like manner, yusurN↓, (K,) and yasaArN↓, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and yasaArapN↓, (S, K,) and mayosarapN↓, and mayosurapN↓, (S, M, K,) of which last Sb says that it is like masorubapN and maXorubapN in not being after the manner of the verb, [but after that of the simple substantive,] (M,) and mayosirapN↓, (K.) Easiness [of circumstances]; (M, K;) competence, or sufficiency; or richness, or wealth, or opulence; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) abundance; (Msb;) [in these senses, also, contr. of EusorN;] and yusoraI↓ signifies [the same; or] easy things or affairs or circumstances; contr. of EusoraI; as also mayosarapN↓. (TA, art. Esr.) You say also, OanoZironiI HatRaI yasaAri↓ [Grant thou me a delay until I shall be in a state of easiness of circumstances, &c.]; in which the last word is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is altered from the inf. n., which is Almayosarapu. (S.) In the Kur. [ii. 280,] some read, fanaZirapN UilaI mayosurihi↓ [Then let there be a postponement, or delay, until his being in a state of easiness of circumstances]: but Akh says, that this is not allowable; for there is no noun of the measure mafoEulN [of this kind]: as to makorumN and maEuwnN, [it is said that] they are pls. [virtually though not in the language of the grammarians] of makorumapN and maEuwnapN. (S.) [On this point, see maOolukN, voce OaluwkN.]
See also yasorN, in two places.
Euwdu yusorK: see Euwdu OusorK, in art. Osr.
yasarN: see yasorN.
Made easy, or facilitated; i. q. muyasRarN: (assumed tropical:) prepared: (K:) or [the game called] Almayosir prepared: or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) anything prepared. (M.)

OaEosaru yasarN A man who works, or does anything, with both his hands [alike]; ambidextrous; ambidexter: (S, M, Msb:) and OaEosaru Oayosaru↓ occurs in a trad., accord. to one relation; but the former is the correct expression: (A'Obeyd:) and the fem. is EasoraMCu yasarapN: (M:) explained before, in art. Esr. (K.)
See also yaAsirN, in six places.
yusurN: see yusorN, in two places.
yasorapN: see yasaArN, throughout.
yusoraI: see yusorN, in two places.
See also Oayosaru.
See also yasaArN, throughout.
yasaArN: see yusorN, in two places.

Also, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and yisaArN↓, (M, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (ISk, IAmb, IF, M, Msb, K *,) or the latter is so, (IDrd, M, K,) or the latter is a variation used for the sake of assimilation to [its syn.] XimaAlN, (Sgh, TA,) or it is vulgar, (IKt, Msb,) and not allowable, (S,) or J is in error in disallowing it, (K,) or it is disapproved because the incipient I with kesr is deemed difficult to pronounce, (M, TA,) but there are three other words commencing like it, namely, yiwaAmN, an inf. n. of yaAwamahu, though this is disallowed by some, and yiEaArN, pl. of yaEorN, and yisaAfN, a proper name of a man, also pronounced with fet-h [to the I]; (TA;) and another form is yasRaArN↓; (Sgh, K;) contr. of yamiynN; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so is yusoraI↓ of yumnaI, (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and yasorapN of yamonapN, (M, A, Msb, K,) and mayosarapN↓ of mayomanapN, (A, Msb, K,) and Oayosaru↓ of Oayomanu: (S:) yasaArN and yusoraI↓ signify The left [hand, or arm, or foot, or leg, or] limb: and the same two words, and yasorapN↓ and mayosarapN↓, the left, meaning the left side or direction or relative location or place: (Msb:) and Oayosaru↓, the left side: or a person [or thing] that is on the left side: (Msb, art. ymn:) [and mayosarapN↓ the left wing of an army:] the pl. of yasaArN is yusurN (Lh, M, K) and yusorN, (K,) or yusarN; (AHn, M;) which last is [also] pl. of yusoraI↓; (TA;) [and the pl. of mayosarapN↓ is mayaAsiru.] You say, qaEada fulaAnN yasorapF↓ Such a one sat on the left side. (S.) And qaEaduwA yamonapF wayasorapF↓, (A, Msb *,) and EalaI yamiynK wayasaArK, and AlyumonaI waAloyusoraI↓, and Almayomanapi waAlomayosarapi↓, (A,) or yamiynFAwayasaArFA, and Eani Aloyamiyni waEani AloyasaAri, and AlyumonaI waAloyusoraI, and Almayomanapi waAlomayosarapi, meaning, They sat on the right side and on the left. (Msb.) And walRaAhu mayaAsirahu↓ [He turned his left parts towards him]. (A.)
yisaArN: see yasaArN.
yasuwrN: see yaAsirN, in two places.
yasiyrN: see yasorN.
Little, or small, in quantity, petty: (S, A, K:) mean, contemptible; paltry; of no weight or worth. (A.)
See also yaAsirN.
yasaArapN: see yusorN.
yasRaArN: see yasaArN.
yaAsirN: see yasorN, first signification.
[Taking the left-hand side or direction: or coming on, or from the direction of, the left hand of a person:] contr. of yaAminN. (S.)
[Dividing a thing into parts, or portions.]

[Hence,] The slaughterer of a camel: (K, TA:) because he divides its flesh into portions: (TA:) the person who superintends the division of the slaughtered camel (M, K) for the game called Almayosir: (K:) pl. [yaAsiruwna and] OayosaArN: (M, K:) A'Obeyd says, I have heard them put yaAsirN in the place of yasarN, [for the explanations of which see what follows,] and yasarN↓ in the place of yaAsirN, (M,) or yasarN↓ and yaAsirN signify the same: and the pl. is OayosaArN: (S, A:) yaAsirN signifies [as explained above, and also] a person who plays with gaming-arrows, (S, Msb, TA,) [at the
game called Almayosir,] for a slaughtered camel; because he is one of those who occasion the slaughter of the camel; and the pl. is [as above and] yaAsiruwna: (TA:) and yasarN↓, i. q. DariybN [which signifies the same; and the person who is entrusted, as deputy, with the disposal of the arrows in the game above mentioned, and who shuffles them in the ribaAbap:] and, [as quasi-pl. of yaAsirN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] a party assembled together at the game called Almayosir: (M, K:) pl. OayosaArN: (M:) and yasiyrN↓ and yasuwrN↓ signify one who contends with another at a game of hazard; syn. qaAmirN: (K:) or yasarN↓ and yasuwrN↓, and also yaAsirN, are applied to one who has, or to whom pertains, a gamingarrow. (IAar, TA.)
Oayosaru [More, and most, easy, or facile; fem. yusoraI].
See also yasaArN.

mwsirN [originally muyosirN,] Possessing competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy, or opulent: (M, K:) pl. mayaAsiyru: (Sb, M, K:) [like mafaAliysu, pl. of mufolisN; and mafaATiyru, pl. of mufoTirN; as though the sing. were mayosuwrN:] but by rule it should be muwsiruwna, for the masc., and muwsiraAtN for the fem. (Abu-l-Hasan, M.)
mayosurN: see yusorN.

mayosirN The game, or play, with unfeathered and headless arrows; (M, K;) the game of hazard which the Arabs play with such arrows; (S, Mgh, Msb;) a game of the Arabs, played [by ten men,] with ten unfeathered and headless arrows: they first slaughtered a camel, [bought on credit, (see below, in this paragraph,)] and divided it into ten portions, or, as some say, [agreeably with what follows,] into twenty-eight: the first arrow was called AlfacRu, and had [one notch and] one portion of the slaughtered camel: the second, AltRawoCamu, and had [two notches and] two portions: the third, AlrRaqiybu, and had [three notches and] three portions: the fourth, AlHilosu, and had [four notches and] four portions: the fifth, AlnRaAfisu, and had [five notches and] five portions; or, as some say, this was the fourth: the sixth, Almusobilu, and had [six notches and] six portions: the seventh, AlmuEalRaI, which was the highest of them, having [seven notches and] seven portions: the eighth and ninth and tenth were called AlsRafiyHu and AlmaniyHu and Alwagodu; and these three had no portions: [the players to whom these three fell had to pay for the slaughtered camel: (see Almusobilu:) whence it appears, that if the camel was divided into ten portions, (see rayomN,) the game must have continued after all these were won, until it was seen whose were the eighth and ninth and tenth arrows; and it seems to be the general opinion that this was the case:] the camel being slaughtered, they collected together the ten arrows, and put them into the ribaAbap, a thing resembling a quiver (kinaAnap), and turned them round about or shuffled them (OajaAluwhaA): [or they employed a person, whom they called HuroDap, to do this:] then they put them into the hand of the judge (AlHakam), who took them forth one after another in the name of one after another of the party; [or they commissioned the HuroDah to do so;] and each took of the portions of the slaughtered camel according to his arrow; but those to whose lots fell the arrows without portions were obliged to pay the price of the slaughtered camel: with the flesh of which they afterwards fed the poor; and him who would not engage with them in the game they reproached, and called a baram: (Sefeenet Er-Rághib, printed at Boolák; p. 637:) [see also raqiybN, and DariybN, and EaXorN:] or any game of hazard; or play for stakes, or wagers: (K:) so that even the game of children with walnuts is included under this name by Mujáhid in his explanation of verse 216 of chap. ii. of the Kur.: (TA:) or anything in which is risk, or hazard: (Kull, p. 321:) or the game of tricktrack, backgammon, or tables; syn. narodN: (Sgh, K:) and chess was called by 'Alee the mayosir of the Persians, or foreigners: (TA:) or the slaughtered camel for which they played: for when they desired to play, they bought on credit a camel for slaughter, and slaughtered it, and divided it into twentyeight portions, or ten portions; and when one [of the arrows] after another came forth [from the ribaAbap] in the name of one man after another, the gain of him for whom came forth those to which belonged portions appeared, and the fine of him for whom came forth [any of the arrows called] the gufol: (K:) so called as though it were a place of division: and so used by the poet Lebeed, who speaks of a fat mayosir. (TA.)
mayosarapN: see yusorN, in two places.
See also yasaArN, in four places.
mayosurapN: see yusorN.
mayosirapN: see yusorN.
muyasRarN Prepared; disposed; made easy, or facile. So in the following words of a trad.: fakulRN muyasRarN limaA xuliqa lahu [And every one is prepared, &c., for that for which he is created]. (TA.)

I. q. zumaAwarodN [q. v.]; (Mgh, K;) app. a post-classical word; so called because easily taken; (Mgh;) in Persian, called nuwaAlaho [or nawaAlaho], (Mgh, K,) and in Egypt termed luqomapu AlqaADiI. (TA.)
muyasRirN, applied to a man, (S, TA,) Having numerous offspring of sheep or goats [and therefore much milk]; (TA;) contr. of mujanRibN. (S, TA.)
mayosuwrN: see yasorN, in three places:
and see also yusorN.
mayaAsiru She-camels that bring forth easily. (TA.)
yaXobN A well known stone; [jasper; peenliarly a whitish kind thereof, found in Mount Imaus: (Golius, from Et-Teyfáshee:)] an arabicized word, from [the Persian] yaXom, q. v. (K.)

4. maA OayoTabahu i. q. maA OaToyabahu: (K:) a dial. form of the latter, or formed from it by transposition: (TA:) and in like manner OayoTibo bihi, i. q. OaToyibo bihi: [both signifying How good, sweet, delicious, or pleasant, is he, or it]. (TA, art. Tyb.)

OayoTabu i. q. OToyabu [More, or most, good, sweet, delicious, or pleasant: and pure]: a correct and chaste dial. form of the latter word. (Ex., from a trad., Ealayokumo biAlOasowadi minohu faUinRahu OayoTabuhu Keep ye to the black thereof; (i. e., of the fruit of the OraAk;) for it is the best of it. But some deny its being a dial. form, [holding it to be formed by transposition]. (TA.)
Oaqobalati AlXRaApu fiI OayoTabatihaA, and OayoTabRatihaA, (the latter form from AZ, TA,) The sheep, or goat, came in the vehemence of her lust for the male. (K.) See also art. Tyb.

1. yafaxahu, (K,) aor.
yafaxa
, because of the guttural letter, or
yafuxa
, accord. to the common rule observed in the K, or
yafixa
, as though it were of the same class as waEada, (TA,) [the last is probably the most correct form, as yaOofixuhu is the aor. of Oafaxahu, of which yafaxahu is a dial. form,] He, or it, hit him, or hurt him, on the part of his head called the yaAfuwx. (K.)

yaAfuwxN [The top of the head;] the part where the anterior and posterior bones of the head meet: [see yaOofuwxN, of which it is a dial. form:] pl. yawaAfiyxu. (TA.) ISd regards this form of pl. as an indication that the I is a radical letter, and therefore mentions it in this art.; (TA;) [and F says the same in art. Ofx: but see that art.].
masRa biyaAfuwxihi AlsRimaAka (assumed tropical:) [He touched Spica Virginis, or Arcturus, with the top of his head]. (A.)
waTiYa fulaAnN yawaAfiyxa Alquruwmi (assumed tropical:) Such a one had lordship and eminence given to him. (A.)
SadaEuwA yaAfuwxa AllRayoli (tropical:) i. q. OadolajuwA [They journeyed in the night; &c.] (A.) [See also art. Ofx.]
mayofuwxN Hit, or hurt, on the part of his head called the yaAfuwx. (K.)

yaAquwtN, [coll. gen. n., The sapphire, of whatever variety: the ruby, oriental ruby, or red sapphire, also called yAqwtN OaHomaru; of which there are several varieties, whereof one is the carbuncle; also called yAqwtN jamoriIRN: the sapphire, commonly so called, or blue sapphire, also called yAqwtN Oazoraqu: and the topaz, oriental topaz, or yellow sapphire, also called yAqwtN OaSofaru: the jacinth, or hyacinth, accord. to Golius, who observes, as on the authority of the Teyfáshee, that by this name are called various gems of the East; four species thereof being enumerated; the red, the yellow, or gold-coloured, the blue, or azure, and the white: that the sapphire and the chrysolite are also thus called: but that, by the word used absolutely, the red jacinth, or hyacinth, commonly called the ruby, is meant: which last remark is agreeable with modern usage:] a well known gem; (K;) of which there are many varieties, (TA,) the most excellent whereof is that called AlyAqwtu AlOaHomaru AlrRumRaAniIRu, (K,) also called AlbahoramaAniIRu; [the finest kind of ruby or carbuncle;] said to be brought from Sarandeeb [or Ceylon]: it has the property of exhilarating, and of conjoining [separated friends]; (TA;) and is profitable for disturbance of the mind (occasioned by the black bile, TA) and palpitation, and weakness of the heart and stomach, if drunk; [being app. reduced to powder for that purpose, as is done with some other gems in the East;] and for congealment of the blood, if hung [upon the person]: (K:) it is a Persian word, (S,) arabicized: (S, K:) of the measure faAEuwlN: n. un. with p; and pl. yawAqiytu. (S.)

1. yaqiZa, aor.
yaqaZa
, (Msb, K,) and yaquZa, aor.
yaquZa
; (Lh, K;) and in the Msb is added yaqaZa, i. e. like Daraba, which is strange; (TA;) [but this I do not find in my copy of the Msb;] inf. n. [of the first] yaqaZN (Msb, K) and yaqaZapN, (Msb, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S,) and [of the second] yaqaAZapN; (Msb, K;) He waked, or woke; did not sleep, or was not sleeping. (Msb, K.)
See also 5.
2: See 4, throughout.
4. AyqZhu (S, &c.) inf. n. UiyqaAZN, (TA,) He awakened him, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) mino niwomihi from his sleep; (S;) as also yqRZhu↓, inf. n. tayoqiyZN; (K;) and AstyqZhu↓. (TA.)
(tropical:) He roused his attention, liloOumuwri to the things, or affairs; (Msb;) as also yqRZhu. (TA.)

AyqZ AlgubaAra (tropical:) He dispersed the dust: (Lth:) and (assumed tropical:) he raised the dust; (Lth, S, Z;) as also yqRZhu↓: (Lth, S:) or, accord. to Az, this is a mistranscription, for baqRaTa AltRuraAba, inf. n. taboqiyTN. (TA.)
5. tyqRZ He became awakened; or he awaked, or awoke; (S, Msb, TA;) mino nawomihi from his sleep; (TA;) as also AstyqZ↓. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

(tropical:) His attention became roused, or he had his attention roused, liloOamori to the thing, or affair; (Msb, * TA;) as also AstyqZ↓, and yaqiZa↓: (Msb:) he became vigilant, wary, or cautious. (TA.) You say also, UilaI Sawotihi huwa yasotayoqiZu↓ (tropical:) [He has his attention roused at his voice, to listen thereto]. (TA.)
10: AstyqZ: see 5, in three places.

(tropical:) It (a woman's anklet or other ornament) made a sound or sounds: (K, TA:) like as one says [in the contr. case], naAma, meaning “ its sound, or sounds, ceased, ” by reason of the fulness of the leg. (TA.)
AstyqZhu: see 4.
yaqoZN: see what next follows, in three places.

yaqiZN and yaqoZN↓ and yaqoZaAnN↓ A man waking, or awake: not sleeping: (K:) or the last has this signification; (S, Msb;) and its fem. is yaqoZaI: (O, Msb, K:) the pl. (K, &c.) of the first (IB, Msb) and second, (IB,) or of the first only, for the second has no broken pl., because of the rareness of faEulN as the measure of an epithet, (Sb, TA,) is OayoqaAZN, (Sb, IB, Msb, K,) which is applied to women as well as to men; (O;) and the pl. of yqZAn is yiqaAZN; (IB;) and the pl. of yqZI is yaqaAZaI. (K.)

And the first (ISk, S, Msb) and ↓second (ISk, S) (tropical:) A man vigilant, wary, cautious, or in a state of preparation; (S, Msb;) having his attention roused: (S:) and intelligent: (Msb:) or a man having his attention much roused, very vigilant, and possessing knowledge and intelligence. (ISk.) [In the TA, each of these two epithets is said to be after the manner of the rel. n.; but they are both part. ns. from yaqiZa as syn. with tyqRZ.] You say also, Alfikori rajulN yaqoZaAnu↓ and mutayaqRiZuhu↓ and yaqiZuhu and yaquZuhu↓ (tropical:) [A man vigilant in mind]. (TA.) And UinRa fulaAnN layaqiZN (assumed tropical:) [Verily such a one is vigilant; not dull, heavy, or listless; lit.] light in head. (AA.)
yaqoZapN: see what next follows.
yaqaZapN A state of waking, or being awake; (S, Mgh, K;) as also yaqoZapN↓, occurring in the saying of the Et-Tihámee,
[Life is a state of sleep, and death is a state of waking; and man between the two is a night journeying phantom]; but most hold it to be used only by poetic license. (TA.)
yaqoZaAnu: see yaqiZN, in two places.
Oabuw AlyaqoZaAni The domestic cock. (K.)
maA raOayotu OayoqaZa minohu (tropical:) [I have not seen any more vigilant, wary, or cautious, than he]. (TA.)
mutayaqRiZN: see yaqiZN.

yalabN Shields, of the kind called tirosapN, (K,) pl. of turosN; or of the kind called daraqN, as is said in the R and M; which two kinds differ in this, that the drq, like the Hajaf, are of skin, or leather, without any wood or sinews (or nerves), whereas trs is a more general appellation: (TA:) or coats of defence, syn. duruwEN, (K,) of the fabric of El-Yemen: (TA:) made [app. whether shields or coats of defence] of skins; (K;) i. e., of the hides of camels: (TA:) or coats of defence (drwE) of the fabric of ElYemen, made of skins sewed together: a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is yalabapN: 'Amr Ibn Kulthoom says:

[Upon us (were) helmets, and leathern coats of defence of the fabric of El-Yemen, and swords that are straight (so accord. to the above reading, of yaqumona, which I find in an excellent copy of the S: but some read yuqamona, which, I think, affords not so good a sense:) and that curve]: (S:) or helmets made of camel's hides: [see also OalabN and OalabapN:] or [head-coverings made of] plaited thongs of leather (nusuwEN) woven together, which are put on the head in lieu of the helmet: (TA:) or skins which are sewed together, and worn on the head, specially: (K:) or skins which are worn beneath the [kind of coat called] diroE, or [beneath that of] diybaAj; one of which is called yalabapN: or skins which are worn like the coats of defence called drwE: or skins of which such coats are made: (TA:) or any defensive coverings, or armour, of skins; not of iron; and hence, shields (daraqN) [of skins] are thus called: a poet says,

[Upon them (are, or were,) all (kinds of) ample coats of mail, smooth and glistening; and in
their hands, round shields of skins]: and yalabN, originally is a name of that skin [of which such coverings are made]: Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee says,

[My coat of mail is smooth and glistening: its cleaving (or sticking close) is an admirable cleaving: and its shield, of good dimensions, is of strips of skin: so accord. to explanations in the S, in arts. Xk and qtr: but I incline to think that jwbhA here is the same as jayobuhaA; and that a word is understood, which makes the meaning to be its opening at the neck and bosom, of good dimensions, is bordered with an edge of thongs]: (S:) or simply skin, or hide. (K.)
Also defensive coverings, or armour, of pieces of felt (lubuwd), with a stuffing of honey (Easal) and sand. (K.)
Also, Steel; (K;) pure iron: (ISh, T, K:) n. un. yalabapN. (TA.) Of this signification, the following hemistich is cited as an ex.,

[And a pulley-axis clearer (in its brightness) than the lustre of pure iron, or steel]: but ISk says that it is by an Arab of the desert, who, hearing the verse of 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom quoted above, erroneously supposed ylb to signify the most excellent kind of iron; and IDrd also asserts that the meaning assigned to it in this hemistich is founded upon a mistake. (TA.) See also OalabapN.
Also, Anything great, big, or large in size. (K.)
yanobuwtN A certain thorny kind of tree, not of the kind called EiDaAh. Mentioned here by IM. See art. nbt. (TA.)
yanobiyv A kind of sea-fish: (IAar, T:) different from the bayoniyv: it is doubtful whether it be Arabic, or a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language. (T.) [See arts. bnv and nbv.]
4. Ayht (as also Awht, TA) It (flesh-meat, K, or a wound, TA) became stinking. (AZ, K.)

Alyahomuwtu A name of the fish upon which is the earth: erroneously written with b [Albhmwt]: so says Esh-Shiháb in the 'Imáyeh. (MF, TA.) [See my translation of the 1001 Nights, note to the Introduction.]

yuwHu, (so accord. to AHat, Mbr, AAF, Kr, Abu-l-'Ala El-Ma'arree, A,) [of the fem. gender, (see buwHu,)] indecl., and without the art. Al (ISd,) accord. to IAmb buwHu, but this is a mistake originating from a corrupt transcription of the word, (IKh, IB, &c.,) and yuwHi, also indecl. like baraAHi, (TA) and yuwHaI, (IAth, K,) names of The sun. (S, art. bwH, K, &c.) [See buwHu.]
